name: deck

deck noun [C]
(FLOOR)
Add to word list
Add to word list
B2 a flat area for walking on, built across the space between the sides of a boat: We sat on deck until it was dark. See also
quarterdeck
sun deck
PhotoGoricki/iStock/Getty Images Plus/GettyImages
one of the floors of a bus: the upper/top deck of the bus
Richard Newstead/The Image Bank/GettyImages
a wooden floor built outside, where people can sit and relax
StanRohrer/E+/GettyImages below decks
on a level of a ship below the main deck: Our cabin was below decks.

More examplesFewer examplesThe ship's deck is composed of steel plates.Two helicopters winched the passengers to safety from the deck of the ship.I felt seasick, so I went up on deck for some fresh air.As the wind increased, the deck of the ship began to heave beneath his feet.On a ship the furniture is often bolted to the deck.

deck noun [C]
(FLOOR)
Add to word list
Add to word list
a wooden floor outside a house, usually with railings (= a low fence) and without a roof: In summer, we always eat out on the deck – except when it rains.
A ship’s deck is a floor laid between the sides of the ship: Waves washed over the deck.
deck noun [C]
(SET OF CARDS)
(also pack) a set of cards used for playing card games
deck verb [T]
(HIT)
to hit someone and cause that person to fall: A key player was decked three times during yesterday’s basketball game.
Phrasal verb
deck out someone/something
